comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The launch was on Wednesday, 7 December 1892, at Mort's Dock (Balmain). Read all about it - SMH 8/12/1892 pp.5-6 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13889051

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Thank you, that is wonderful! We'll update our captions and dates. I have also added a larger version here so we can see more detail. The officials could be in that smart little group to the right of the ship.

AB

From the newspaper article: 

"...his Excellencv the Governor proceeded to launch in the presence of about 1000 onlookers, and as the blocks were driven awayand the craft began to make for the water he broke a bottle of wine over her bows, and amidst loud cheering christened the new pilot steamer '"Captain Cook."  ...her elegant proportions wore displayed to the spectators.
...The vessel was designed by and built under the superintendence of Mr W D Cruickshank, the senior Government engineer surveyor, and is a very handsome model, with good lines for speed. She is constructed of steel in accordance with Lloyd's highest requirements. Her principal dimensions are -length between perpendiculars, 155ft ; length overall, 180ft; beam moulded, 25ft; depth, moulded, 15ft. ..."

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] Yes, the old newspaper reports (when you can find them) really give life and reason to otherwise ho-hum old photographs.  The amount of detail (names, ship's specifications, dignitaries' pompous and boring speeches) recorded is amazing,  and sometimes I feel as if I was there.  Time travel via flickr!

Also buried in the newspaper article is a description of the figurehead (of Captain Cook) "cast in one piece with great success.  It is the first attempt that has been made at a statuary founding in the colonies."

comment.author: 77487342@N03
comment._content: Three years later Mort's was used in the repairing of the steamer 'Cammeray' which sunk after a collision with the steamer 'Sydney'. The Contract was issued to my Ancestor Alfred Whetton and Sons. Cite: The Sydney Morning Herald. (1895, June 26). The Sydney Morning Herald (NSW : 1842 - 1954), p. 7. from nla.gov.au/nla.news-article14009150

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/77487342@N03] Thanks for the addtional information!
- AG

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: The Sydney Mail recycled the SMH report...not really plagiarism, the SM and SMH came out of the same stable...The SM included an illustration drawn from a pic by Kerry & Co...which was taken from the other side of the dock...the pic is on p. 1425...the SM sketch pales in comparison with this fantastic action shot - news.google.com/newspapers?id=zhhQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=l5UDA...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:

comment.author: 94284603@N02
comment._content: Does anyone know the hull, stack and mast colours?  Thanks.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/94284603@N02] @buzzard35 - I left a message on the ANMM photo - they might know. I recently came across this Henry King photo of all the 'nobs' outside Mort's Dock Office on the occasion of this very ship launching. Somebody from the Mort family has helpfully added names acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/ItemViewer.aspx?itemid=852734&am... From this wonderful Mort Family album - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemdetailpaged.aspx?itemid=430589#

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/94284603@N02] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] The Powerhouse have a model of CAPTAIN COOK III (you may have seen this already) which may be of interest to you. We have a watercolour painting of its predecessor, CAPTAIN COOK dated c 1920 (unfortunately it isn't online) in which the hull appears black and the mast & stack are ochre / mustard coloured. If we come across any more info we'll post it here! Cheers
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
